                               JUDGMENT

This is an Application under Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (hereinafter referred to as "the Act") for appointment of Arbitrator/s.

2. Prayer clause A of the Application reads as follows:

"a. Appoint an independent second arbitrator and an independent third/presiding arbitrator for adjudication ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 3 of disputes relating to Claim Nos.37 to 40 forming subject matter of the disputes between the applicant and the Respondent No.1 under Arbitration Notice dated 31.01.2020."

.

3. The brief facts leading to the filing of this Application are narrated hereunder:

(a) The petitioner - Patel-Gamon Joint Venture, is a joint venture comprising of Patel AR Engineering Limited and Gammon India Limited. The petitioner is engaged in the business of civil engineering and constructions.
(b) Respondent No.1-Satluj Jal Vidyut Nigam Limited (SJVNL) is functioning under the administrative control of respondent No.2-Ministry of Power, Government of India.

Respondent No.1 was incorporated in 1988 as a joint venture of the Government of India and the Government of Himachal Pradesh. Respondent No.1-SJVNL is a listed company having shareholder pattern of 61.05% with Government of India, 26.85% with Government of Himachal Pradesh and rest of 12.10% with public. Respondent No.1 is inter alia involved in and is responsible for the development and management of Rampur Hydro-Electric Project ("RHEP") in the State of Himachal Pradesh.

::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 4

(c) Respondent No. 2 is the Ministry of Power, Government of India, through Secretary (Power). Under the Arbitration Clause which is the subject-matter of the present Application, .

respondent No. 2-Ministry of Power, Government of India is required to appoint the third arbitrator for adjudication of disputes between the petitioner and respondent No.1.

(d) Pursuant to a tender issued by respondent No. 1- SJVNL for construction and civil engineering works in relation to Rampur Hydro-Electric Project (RHEP), the petitioner and respondent no.1-SJVNL entered into a construction contract dated 15 March 2007 ("Contract") being "Package-2.0 (ICB No. CCD RHEP-402-2) Construction of Civil Works For HRT From Sta 12900M To Sta. 15088M Surge Shaft, Pressure Shafts, Valve House, Power House Complex, TRT, Adits And Hydro Mechanical Works Contract Agreement No. RHEP -

10/2007". Disputes and differences arose under the Contract.

The petitioner had raised several claims against respondent No. I-SJVNL arising under various clauses of the Contract. The subject matter of the present Application are four claims, i.e. claim Nos. 37 to 40. These claims were disputed by respondent No.1-SJVNL and the petitioner referred these ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 5 claims to a Dispute Board under Clause 20 of the General Conditions of the Contract (GCC).

4. It would be apposite to extract Clause 20 of the GCC in its .

entirety. It reads as follows:-

"20. The notice shall be given as soon as practicable, and not later than 28 days after the Contractor became aware, or should have become aware, of the event or circumstance.
If the Contractor fails to give notice of a claim within such period of 28 days, the Time for Completion shall not be extended, the Contractor shall not be entitled to additional payment, and the Employer shall be discharged from all liability in connection with the claim. Otherwise, the following provisions of this Sub-Clause shall apply. (a) this fully detailed claim shall be considered as interim

and

and/or (ii) the additional payment (if any) to which the Contractor is entitled under the Contract.

20.2 Appointment of the Dispute Board Disputes shall be referred to a DB for decision in accordance the Dispute Board with Sub-Clause 20.4 [Obtaining Dispute Board's Decision] The Parties shall appoint a DB by the date stated in the Contract Data.

The DB shall comprise, as stated in the Contract Data, either one or three suitably qualified persons ("the members"), each of whom shall be fluent in the language for communication defined in the Contract and shall be a professional experienced in the type of construction involved in the Works and with the interpretation of contractual documents. sole member or each of the three members shall incorporate by reference the General Conditions of Dispute Board Agreement contained in the Appendix to these General Conditions, with such amendments as are agreed between them.

The terms of the remuneration of either the sole member or each of the three members, including the remuneration of any expert whom the DB consults, shall be mutually agreed upon by the Parties when agreeing the terms of appointment of the member or such expert (as the case may be). Each Party shall be responsible for paying one-half of this remuneration.

If a member declines to act or is unable to act as a result of death, disability, resignation or termination of appointment, a replacement shall be appointed in the same manner as the replaced person was required to have been nominated or agreed upon, as described in this Sub-Clause.

Unless otherwise agreed by both Parties, the appointment of the DB (including each member) shall expire when the discharge referred to in Sub Clause 14.12 [Discharge) shall have become effective.

20.3 Failure to Agree on the composition of the Dispute Board If any of the following conditions apply, namely:

(a) the Parties fail to agree upon the appointment of the sole member of the DB by the date stated in the first paragraph of Sub-Clause 20.2 ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 9 [Appointment of the Dispute Board],

three persons by such date,

(c) the Parties fail to agree upon the appointment of the third member (to act as chairman) of the DB by such date, or

(d) the Parties fail to agree upon the appointment of a replacement person within 42 days after the date on which the sole member or one of the three members declines to act or is unable to act as a result of death, disability, resignation or termination of appointment, then the appointing entity or official named in the Contract Data shall, upon the request of either or both of the Parties and after due consultation with both Parties, appoint this member of the DB. This appointment shall be final and conclusive. Each Party shall be responsible for paying one half of the remuneration of the appointing entity or official.

20.4 Obtaining Dispute Board's Decision If a dispute (of any kind whatsoever) arises between the Parties in connection with, or arising out of, the Contract or the execution of the Works, including any dispute as to any certificate, determination, instruction, opinion or valuation of the Engineer, either Party may refer the dispute in writing to the DB for its decision, with copies to the other Party and the Engineer. Such reference shall state that it is given under this Sub-Clause.

Both Parties shall promptly make available to the DB all such additional information, further access to the Site, and ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 10 appropriate facilities, as the DB may require for the purposes of making a decision on such dispute. The DB shall be deemed to be not acting as arbitrator(s).

Within 84 days after receiving such reference, or within .

such other period as may be proposed by the DB and approved by both Parties, the DB shall give its decision, which shall be reasoned and shall state that it is given under this Sub-Clause. The decision shall be binding on both Parties, who shall promptly give effect to it unless and until it shall be revised in an amicable settlement or an arbitral award as described below. Unless the Contract has already been abandoned, repudiated or terminated, the Contractor shall continue to proceed with the Works in accordance with the Contract.

If either Party is dissatisfied with the DB's decision, then either Party may, within 28 days after receiving the decision, give notice to the other Party of its dissatisfaction and intention to commence arbitration. If the DB fails to give its decision within the period of 84 days (or as otherwise approved) after receiving such reference, then either Party may, within 28 days after this period has expired, give notice to the other Party of its dissatisfaction and intention to commence arbitration.

In either event, this notice of dissatisfaction shall state that it is given under this Sub-Clause, and shall set out the matter in dispute and the reason(s) for dissatisfaction.

Except as stated in Sub-Clause 20.7 [Failure to Comply with Dispute Board's Decision] and Sub-Clause 20.8 [Expiry of Dispute Board's Appointment], neither Party shall be entitled to commence arbitration of a dispute unless a notice of dissatisfaction has been given in accordance with this Sub-Clause.

If the DB has given its decision as to a matter in dispute to both Parties, and no notice of dissatisfaction has been given by either Party within 28 days after it received the DB's decision, then the decision shall become final and binding upon both Parties.

5. The case of the petitioner in the Application is as under:

(i) In terms of Clause 20.4 of the GCC, the Dispute Board is required to give its decision on the claims within a period of 84 days after receiving the reference. Clause 20.4 further states that Dispute Board shall be deemed to have received such a reference on the date when it is received by the Chairman of the Dispute Board. In the present case, the reference was received by the Dispute Board on 06.11.2019. It is further stated in Clause 20.4 of the GCC that upon expiry of the period of 84 days, if a decision is not rendered by the Dispute Board, either party may notify the other party of its dissatisfaction and intention to commence arbitration ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 13 within 28 days after this period has expired.
(ii) It is not in dispute that in pursuance of Clause 20.4, both the petitioner and respondent No.1-SJVNL consented before the then Dispute .

Board in its 60th meeting held on 14.12.2017 and 15.12.2017 that all future claims after claim No.34 will be decided within 84 days from the day it is received by the Dispute Board.

(iii) The aforesaid period of 84 days for the Dispute Board to render a decision in relation to Claim Nos.37 to 40 being the subject matter of the present dispute, has expired on 29.01.2020. Even after the expiry of 84 days of a reference of Claim Nos.37 to 40 to the Dispute Board, no decision was rendered by the Dispute Board. Even as on the date of issuance of the notice of dissatisfaction and invocation of arbitration on 31.01.2020, the Respondent No.1-SJVNL had failed to file its pleadings before the Disputes Board. The reasons for non-adjudication of Claims before the Dispute Board within the prescribed timelines are attributable solely to respondent No. 1-SJVNL and due to the conduct of respondent No.1-SJVNL, the possibility of a timely adjudication and decision on the petitioner's claims by the Disputes Board had been rendered impossible.

Under Clause 20.6 of the GCC, the petitioner and respondent No.1-SJVNL have agreed that any disputes not resolved by the Dispute Board within 84 days shall be finally settled by arbitration as per the Act.

(iv) Upon expiry of period of 84 days and since no decision was rendered by the Dispute Board, the petitioner issued a notice dated ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 14 31.01.2020 (Arbitration Notice) of dissatisfaction and invocation of arbitration to respondent No.1-SJVNL for claim Nos.37 to 40 under Clause 20.4 read with Clause 20.6 of the GCC.

.

(v) The petitioner also informed respondent No.1-SJVNL of its compliance with the pre-arbitral proceedings and clarified that the petitioner did not see any scope of amicable settlement under Clause 20.5 of the GCC. The petitioner conveyed to respondent No. 1-SJVNL- (i) its preferred venue of arbitration at Delhi; and (ii) its nomination of Sh. Suresh Chandra Gupta (First Arbitrator) as petitioner's nominee arbitrator along with his consent letter and declaration under Section 12(1)(b) of the Act.

The petitioner also invited respondent No.1-SJVNL to nominate its arbitrator (Second Arbitrator) and to provide its response in respect of the venue of the arbitration within 21 days from the receipt of the Arbitration Notice, which period expired on 22.02.2020.

vi) Upon the resignation of the erstwhile nominee Dispute Board member of respondent No. 1-SJVNL appointed its replacement nominee its member Ajay Patiyal. Immediately thereafter on 25.7.2018, the Applicant granted its approval to Mr. Patiyal's appointment.

(vii) By its letter dated 25.10.2018, the Respondent No. 1-SJVNL acknowledged the reconstitution of the Dispute Board and stated that this reconstituted Dispute Board "shall adjudicate the claims arising in future other than claim nos. 27 to 36". At this point of time, there was no indication from the Respondent No. 1-SJVNL that it would require ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 15 execution of a fresh Dispute Board Agreement or setting up of new procedures before Claim Nos. 37 to 40 could be adjudicated by the Dispute Board.

.

(viii) By a letter dated 04.11.2019 issued by the Applicant through its counsel, Trilegal, vide email dated 06.11.2019, the Applicant submitted the subject-matter claims i.e. Claim Nos. 37 to 40, to the Dispute Board for adjudication.

(ix) By its letters dated 26.11.2019 and 12.12.2019, the respondent No. 1-SJVNL requested the Dispute Board to convey a suitable venue and date for meeting "in order to start the proceedings" in relation to Claim Nos. 37 to 40. Therefore, even at this stage, there was no indication from the respondent No. 1-SJVNL that it would require execution of a fresh Dispute Board Agreement or setting up of new procedures before Claim Nos. 37 to 40 could be adjudicated by the Dispute Board. To the contrary, the respondent No. 1-SJVNL had placed on record its categorical intention of starting the adjudication proceedings as per Clause 20.4 of the GCC.

(x) In view of the Applicant's fresh claims under letter dated 04.11.2019 and the respondent No. 1-SJVL's requests dated 26.11.2019 and 12.12.2019 to "start the proceedings", the Dispute Board was pleased to issue detailed procedure for submission of rebuttal and rejoinder vide its letter dated 20.12.2019. Amongst others, ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 16 the Dispute Board directed the respondent No. I-SJVNL to file its replies to Claim Nos. 37 to 40 within 42 days from the date of receipt of the claims.

.

(xi) Seeing that it would not be able to comply with the timelines as directed by the Dispute Board, the respondent No. I-SJVNL took a complete u-turn from its earlier position to "start the proceedings" and instead, by its letter dated 26.12.2019, for the very first time requested the Dispute Board to convey suitable venue and date of meeting for "signing of DB agreement and establishing procedure to be applied in deciding dispute". It became apparent that the respondent No. I-SJVNL was making all possible efforts to delay and prolong the adjudication of the Applicant's claims, as it had attempted to do in the past in relation to Claim Nos. 27-36 (presently in arbitration).

(xii) By its letter dated 14.01.2020, the Applicant put on record to the Dispute Board its strong objections on the stand taken by the respondent No. 1-SJVNL in its letter dated 26.12.2019. The Applicant also stated that it was clear from a reading of Clause 20.4 of the GCC that the Dispute Board shall give its decision on the claims "within 84 days after receiving such reference, or within such other period as may be proposed by the DB and approved by both Parties". In the absence of the Applicant's approval to any extended period, the said 84 days' period has started running from 06.11.2019, i.e. from the date on which ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 17 the said claims were received by Hon'ble Chairman of the Dispute Board, notwithstanding any objections from the respondent No. 1- SJVNL. As such, it was the Applicant's firm stand that it shall be entitled .

to the contractual consequences that ensue upon the expiry of the said 84 days' period, including by referring the said Claim Nos. 37 to 40 to arbitration. Nonetheless, in light of the Dispute Board's directions in its letter dated 02.01.2020, the Applicant agreed to attend the Dispute Board meetings scheduled to be held on 17.01.2020 and 18.01.2020. It was clarified that the Applicant's attendance in this meeting would be without prejudice to its strong objections to the conduct of the respondent No. 1-SJVNL and the Applicant reserved its right to respond and contest the content of the respondent No. 1-SJVNL's letter dated 26.12.2019 at the scheduled Dispute Board meetings.

(xiii) The then-prevailing Procedural Rules of the Dispute Board provided that "if reconstituted for some reason, the date of reference of dispute to the DB shall be the date when initial reference was made by the Claimant for the first time to the DB."

(xiv) In response to the Applicant's letter dated 14.01.2020, the respondent No. 1-SJVNL issued a letter dated 16.01.2020 through its counsel, Khaitan & Co. LLP, wherein the respondent No. 1-SJVNL took another new stand insofar as it now sought to contend that "no validly constituted Disputes Board exists under the terms of the Agreement ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 18 between the parties" upon the resignation of Mr. H. C. Bhardwaj on 15.05.2018. This was clearly an after-thought and directly contrary to the provisions of the Dispute Board Agreement dated 17.12.2008 which .

provided in clear terms that "The DB is to be in operation throughout the duration of the contract". It, therefore, became apparent to the Applicant that the respondent No. 1-SJVNL is taking one desperate measure after another to somehow delay the adjudicatory process before the Dispute Board.

(xv) At the meetings of the Dispute Board held on 17.01.2020 and 18.01.2020, the Applicant reiterated the position taken by it in its letter dated 14.01.2020. Once the respondent No.1-SJVNL took the position that "no validly constituted Disputes Board exists under the terms of the Agreement between the parties", the Applicant became contractually entitled to directly initiate arbitration under Clause 20.8 without waiting for the expiry of the 84-day period before the Dispute Board. In any event, keeping in view the sanctity of the contractual provisions relating to the pre-arbitration process and in order to avoid the possibility of any technical or procedural objections from the respondent No. 1-SJVNL to further delay the adjudication of Claim Nos. 37-40, the Applicant decided to take a conscious decision of waiting for the said period of 84-days to expire and issued the Arbitration Notice only thereafter on 31.01.2020. Even though during the Dispute Board meeting held on ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 19 18.01.2020, the Applicant signed a fresh Tripartite Dispute Board Agreement, however, this was strictly without prejudice to the Applicant's consistent position as stated in the meetings of the Dispute .

Board held on 17.01.2020 and 18.01.2020 and in its letter dated 14.01.2020.

(xvi) In view of the above, once the period of 84 days starting from 06.11.2019 expired on 29.01.2020, the Applicant issued the Arbitration Notice on 31.01.2020.

(xvii) Thereafter, by its letter dated 17.02.2020, the Applicant informed the Dispute Board that by virtue of the issuance of the Arbitration Notice, the Dispute Board had become functus officio in relation to Claim Nos. 37-40. Without prejudice to the same, the Applicant in good faith agreed to assist the Dispute Board in finalizing the minutes of the meetings held on 17.01.2020 and 18.01.2020 (as requested by the Dispute Board vide its email dated 02.02.2020).

However, the Applicant was of the considered view that a deliberation on the procedural rules was not required at this stage and the same may be finalized if and when fresh claims are raised before the Dispute Board.

(xviii) In reference to the Applicant's letter dated 17.02.2020, the respondent No.1-SJVNL issued a letter dated 24.02.2020 through its counsel, Khaitan & Co. LLP, to the Dispute Board calling out the ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 20 Arbitration Notice to be non-est and bad in law, albeit on certain flimsy, unfounded and incorrect grounds.

(xix) By a letter dated 26.02.2020 issued to the Dispute Board, the .

Applicant strongly denied the content of the letter dated 24.02.2020 issued by Respondent No.1-SJVNL through its counsel, Khaitan & Co.

LLP. The Applicant clarified that its position remains that upon issuance of the Arbitration Notice on 31.01.2020, the Dispute Board became functus officio in relation to Claim Nos. 37-40. Additionally, based on the position taken by respondent No. 1-SJVNL in the said letter dated 24.02.2020, there is clearly no scope for an adjudication in any forum other than in an arbitration.

(xx) Though Clause 20.6 of the GCC provides that in case of a dispute between respondent No.1-SJVNL and a domestic contractor, (the petitioner in the present case), the third arbitrator is to be appointed by respondent No.2, Secretary, MOP-GOI there exists circumstances that raise justifiable doubt as to the independence and impartiality of such arbitrator to be appointed by respondent No.2, Secretary, MOP-GOI and circumstances which warrant appointment of an independent arbitrator by ignoring the procedure prescribed under Clause 20.6 for the following reasons:

(a) the respondent No. 1-SJVNL is a joint venture of the Government of India and the Government of Himachal Pradesh having shareholders pattern of 61.05% with ::: Downloaded on - 12/01/2023 20:29:59 :::CIS 21 Government of India, 26.85% with Government of Himachal Pradesh and rest of 12.10% with public, and it is the Respondent No. 1-SJVNL's public position on its website (http://sjvn.nic.in/company-) that it falls "under administrative .
control of Ministry of Power, Government of India";
(b) there is no doubt that the Respondent No. 1-SJVNL's affairs and activities are regulated and managed by the Respondent No. 2;
(c) In its Annual Report 2018-19, the Respondent No. 1-SJVNL has stated that "As per the Articles of Association, IBAI 402 the power to appoint Directors vests with the President of India acting through the Administrative Ministry i.e., Ministry of Power";

(d) In its Annual Report 2018-19, the Respondent No. 1- SJVNL also states that its Whole Time Director (Civil) was appointed "pursuant to the orders of Ministry of Power";

(e) in its Annual Report 2017-18, the Respondent No. 1- SJVNL also states that its Chairman and Managing Director as well as Part-Time Official Director (Gol Nominee) were appointed "pursuant to the orders of Ministry of Power";

(xxi) The officials of the respondent No.2 themselves hold key position in the Board and Management of respondent No.1-SJVNL and the administrative functioning and control of respondent No.1- SJVNL vests with respondent No.2.
